name: Foundry MiniGlaciar
Gabriel the Master Grappler
Top 8 @ Canadian Nationals 2014
description: Andy deck with a few meta call cards, notably Scrubber for NEH and Data Dealer for Shi Kyu and Domestic Sleepers.

name: Top 8 @ Canadian Nationals 2014
description: Typical Midseason Hell shenanigans.

name: Rielle Talk 1.0
description:
Kit has always been my favorite; a cyborg after my own heart. Ever since the early days when people shrugged at her saying "Lol 10 Influence," I've been running Kit, toying around with different methods like Big Rig, Personal Workshop, Torch, Paintbrush, Yogasaurus, Omnidrive, Silver Bullet and other themes. Here is something that I feel is a good, happy medium between a lot of Kit's strategies.

The core to this deck: Cyber-Cypher - One of these (or an SMC) on turn one means you're getting into that server. With an insanely cheap install cost coupled with cost effective running, this is by far my favorite Decoder in Kit's arsenal. Scavenge should be used to "retarget" your CC's on new servers.

Magnum Opus and Kati Jones are the driving economic force, though an early Professional Contacts adds up quickly. Overall, running should be fairly efficient between CC's high strength, Lockpick, and Desperado. I even threw in a copy of Net Celebrity which isn't bad considering it pays for itself in one run, but honestly, I haven't been able to test it yet; it's mostly there just in case all of those amazing Corp currents start seeing play.

Dig deep with Nerve Agent and R&D Interface; this will force them to overstock on protection. 1 copy of Datasucker is in the deck because, honestly, I had 1 influence left. Datasucker is just such a good card, especially paired with Desperado and since you can tutor for it, it's nice to have in there for the games you know you'll want it.

Overall, memory isn't a problem thanks to Leprechaun; use them to store Opus, SMC, and Paintbrush which is just about the cheapest memory you can ask for (2 credit install in order to free up 3 memory). But one Akamatsu Mem Chip is still in (along with your Desperado memory) just in case, though that card might be cut if Leprechaun continues to be awesome.

Also note that Paintbrush is NOT a must in this deck. Tinkering will do work on its own. But, if you're running against huge mega servers, it's best to be turning everything into Code Gates since Inti isn't efficient and Femme is rarely used to actually break Sentries.

Honestly, I foresee this deck morphing very soon. The next datapack will include Refractor, a shiny new decoder that uses Stealth credits. Once that hits, this deck will likely forego Cyber-Cypher and also find room for Cloak/Dagger. But I look forward to continuing to refine this deck until its something special.

name: Big Toys
description:
A straightforward deck using Test Run and Self-modifying Code to tutor out Magnum Opus ASAP to fund the big toys.

Legwork and The Maker's Eye for surprise accesses.

Comments appreciated, been refining this for quite awhile, looking forward to it being torn apart by internet wolves :)

name: Nasir Parasite
description: Classic Recurring Parasite combo, using Nasir + Personnal Workshop as fuel for economy. The deck has no real bad match-up, but is very unstable due to high dependency on Personal Workshop.

name: Nasir, ICE Explorer - Pre SB
Biotic Hub  (17/08/2014)
description:
3/4 today. Won vs Kate, Reina, Ken Tenma, Lost vs Kate.

Will o the wisp was a very disappointing test, although I did misplay it into a new server one game when I should have installed it into HQ or R&D, so that was my bad. I am very hapy with the ace as it is. Rototurret catches a lot of people off guard. I sure would like another SanSan.

name: Offshore Accounts (17/08/2014)
description:
Went 1/4 today. Won against HBFoundry, lost to Weyland BABWx2, Jinteki RP.

I know this decks worst match up is vs Weyland scorch and I was unlucky enough to come up against it my first two games. The game vs RP went to time with only a single agenda point scored by them so I am not looking into that one too hard. Did very well vs Foundry glacier.

name: NBN: Near-Eart Hub Fast Advance
Noise Back to Basics
Efficient Together
Gotta Pay For That ICE
Hatred
description:
If you could bottle pure, unmitigated malice, then transform it into a deck, this one is probably pretty close to what you'd end up with. Practically every Anarch source of denial is available in this deck, from creds (Reina, Vamp, Lamprey) to cards (DLR, Keyhole, Imp) to clicks (through forcing the corp to purge viruses).

This is really an anti-deck, designed to take advantage of corps who only lightly ice centrals to try to keep you out then either go for fast advance or the shell game. This could be to the detriment of your matchup with glacier decks, but I believe it's a tradeoff worth making.

How to Play & Card Choices

Your primary game plan is to hit HQ over and over, building up cash through Desperado and making the corp poor with Lamprey. If HQ is made inaccessible, either Parasite something or switch to R&D with Keyhole until you find Sneakdoor.

Dyson and Underworld Contact give you fantastic clickless econ; Vamp turns on DLR in addition to ruining the corps that do best when they're above a certain credit threshold (NBN FA, Jinteki PE).

Overmind is for early-game aggression and gets you through Lotus Field; with the additional sources of memory, you can get a decent number of counters on it.

Alternatives

I tried to stay away from Siphon in this (because everyone expects it in post-Anatomy-of-Anarchy Reina) in favour of the more relentless Desperado. It's really a trade-off between having more efficient runs overall vs. that single power turn that ruins the corp.

If you find the clickless econ doesn't get set up fast enough (possible), or you're not using all your memory (less likely), you can take out the Dyson-Underworld package for any of:

  • Nerve Agent or Medium, because multi-access is good
  • Kati Jones, to power up your Vamps (which might be a good choice in any case)
  • Dirty Laundry, for run-based econ
  • Hemorrhage, if you want to hate even more on those corps that leave plenty of undefended remotes
  • Stimhack, to get in when the corp thought you couldn't
  • Joshua B., again to turn on DLR (and because extra clicks are good)
  • Knight, if you like Knight

Data Leak Reversal is also removable. It's mostly used as protection for the Underworld Contacts, because DLR is the more immediate threat if you're tagged.

Disclaimer

I haven't tested this deck, and tuning is definitely needed to see what works and what doesn't. Any feedback would be greatly appreciated.

name: Lost and Foundry
description:
Debating between Mother Goddess and Chimera ice. MG adds to the NEXT, Chimera is a pure Sentry play. Also, Flare is expensive, so I might want to drop it for another barrier.

I'd like to find space for another upgrade, but I am not sure where to make room. Do I drop Green Level Clearance and/or Blue Level Clearance?

name: Kate, Lucky Pro (Top 8, Canadian Nationals 2014)
Near Earth Hub: Robot Club (Top 8, Canadian Nationals 2014)
Tennin Biotic Trick
description: Protect centrals with taxing ice to advance ice for free, then fast-advance with Biotic Labor and Trick of Light.

name: Run Kate Run
description: aaa

name: Weyland: Power You Can Rely On
description: The idea here is to use Blue Sun's ability both as an econ generating force (paired with Oversight AI, The Root, PrioReq, and Amazon Industrial Zone) and to pick up assets (Elizabeth Mills, Server Diagnostics) when they're either threatened or I need to move them/re-use their rez ability/take them off the board to install ice.

name: Celebrity Hubbub - North American Nationals Top 8
description:
This is the Corp Deck I piloted to first place in Swiss (9-1) of the top 64 players in the North American Nationals. I wound up ultimately getting 5th place in the elimination rounds, which I was quite happy with!

My thinking with this deck was to get the runner to waste time on assets that some NEH decks rely on but to have the back up economy (Celebrity) if they did end up trashing everything. Celebrity Gift has the obvious downside of showing your hand to your opponent but combined with Jackson I was usually able to keep them guessing. Overall, the ability to bounce back from 3 to 10 credits is incredibly useful.

This deck runs more ice than a typical fast advance deck, partly for parasites but also for flexibility and consistency. TMI is in there for HQ account siphon protection, which was one of the few problems I had while testing the deck. TMI is also amazing against Nasir and won me a really close game in Swiss against him. Lotus field is a wonderful card against anyone who doesn't pack Atman and I definitely don't regret slotting two of them over Eli.

Data Raven without tag punishment may be questionable to some but I found it to be very effective in a tournament setting, almost always forcing the runner to jack out and play slowly, fearing Scorched Earth. Some players even went as far to Femme it, which is a fantastic trade in tempo.

Other than that it's a fairly standard NEH deck, take it for a test drive and see how it treats you!

name: Striving for Perfection v2 (Jinteki Q1 2014 Earnings Cast)
description:
Jinteki Q1 2014 Earnings Cast Transcript

OPERATOR: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Jinteki's first quarter 2014 Results Conference Cast. This cast is being recorded for replay purposes.

All participants are currently in a listen-only mode. Following the conference, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. At this time, I would like to turn the cast over to Senior Director Toshiyuki Sakai for introductory remarks.

Slide: Jinteki Q1 2014 Earnings Cast

SAKAI: Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone. We announced Jinteki's first quarter results for the 2014 fiscal year after the close of trading today. Our financial results should now be available at our Investor Relations site, as will be the recorded cast for this cast.

Before we dive into our results, we would like to call attention to our recent showing at Gen Con Nationals, where our sysops were able to demonstrate, in a friendly setting, how our latest offerings perform against the most notorious black hat hackers. We were proud to see our security tech go undefeated during the final day, 64-person event. It also dominated, for the most part, the 128-person precursor event. Yesterday, renowned architect Lukas Litzsinger, co-creator of the net's source protocols, ran a field test against our technology and flatlined after we forced him into a series of lose-lose situations.

We believe the results from Nationals and the previous quarter validate the recent infrastructure updates Jinteki has put into place, as well as our controversial partnership with competitor Haas-Bioroid. After studying the results reported by db0's Untrashable trials and our own in-house experiments with variants, we managed to implement an overwhelming number of assets and network infrastructure upgrades, requiring opponents to expend a considerable amount of time and resources to attack our properties, especially with the introduction of Encryption Protocols.

Slide: Credits Rule Everything Around Me // Econ

We are pleased to report that our fixed assets that have generated a healthy drip economy for Jinteki in the previous quarter, if not a flood. Thanks to the success of our Sundew efforts, PAD Campaigns, and Mental Health Clinic branches, we dramatically increased revenues year-over-over for the quarter.

This approach is vulnerable to attacks from outside forces -- unlike safe bets with hedge funds or Jinteki's previous lucrative efforts with tiny giraffes -- but protecting these resources with taxing security measures can ward them off until we can deluge our servers with assets and Encryption Protocols. We have also recruited several talented students from Levy University as Interns to recover and re-install lost Sundews, critical upgrades, and even ICE [Intrusion Countermeasures Electronics] cheaply.

It's worth noting that we recently hired the esteemed Jackson Howard to assist with our cloning initiatives. He's been invaluable in not only helping accelerate R&D on economy assets and ICE, but also resurrecting cancelled but promising projects.

I will now turn the cast over to Ms. Tori Hanzo to share the moves we've made this previous quarter to cut our operating costs.

Slide: Protect Ya Neck // Traps

HANZO: Thank you, Senior Director. As you know, Jinteki retired its long-running Junebug bioengineering project last quarter in favor of inexpensive but effective deterrents, such as Shocks, Snares, and Shi.Kyūs. Though we have since suspended these so-called "ambush" disincentives, we continue to employ a Ronin, hostile tech that can serve as a distraction and a potential punishment for careless runners.

Furthermore, we are capitalizing on Hokusai Grids to protect weak points where runners can access, serving as stopgaps until we can install stronger ICE, or adding an extra bite to Sundew servers that our opponents try to access. These facilities are expensive for intruders to disable, and hackers sometimes avoid them completely, expecting them to be safeguarded by Caprice. Her reputation amongst the "runner" community is formidable, and that alone is often more than enough to dissuade them from attacking.

Our Chairman can talk more at length about Caprice.

Slide: Only Built for Caprice Linx // Upgrades

HIRO: Yes, we recently welcomed Ms. Caprice Nisei back to the fold and integrated her into our countermeasures. We have been able to utilize her uncanny abilities and the detective skills she picked up during her time working with the New Angeles Police Department to block illegal incursions into our servers. For runners who do manage to make it past our defenses and even siphon our funds, we have an agreement with media corporation NBN allowing us to track these criminals when possible to close their accounts.

As our Senior Director noted earlier, we have partnered with Haas-Bioroid for a limited exchange of technology, which includes an agreement to lease the company's Ash bioroid line. Pairing Ms. Nisei with these bioroids forces our opponents to waste a significant amount of credits and time to access any agendas or assets. Taking this into account with our Encryption Protocols, expensive assets that hackers cannot ignore, and work compression advantages, we are able to easily open windows for the company to push through its initiatives.

One of our sysops will now discuss the lengths Jinteki has gone to in order to protect our servers and those initiatives.

Slide: Clan In Da Front // ICE

MIDORI: Okay, while we tend to install fewer and more porous ICE than some of our competitors, we try to make up for it with adaptable ICE like Chimera, as well as cheap but annoying ICE like Yagura and Pup, which work great to slow down runners looking to get an early advantage on us. We also have some nasty and taxing ICE like Komainu and Tsurugi, which can bleed those hackers dry if they want to make repeated runs on our servers.

Sure, they're not the strongest ICE and susceptible to virus attacks -- unless you count our new Lotus Field tech -- but keep in mind that it costs us nothing to bring them back online if they're taken down, thanks to the Interns we've got working around the clock. The Swordsman ICE we've thrown in is also a mean surprise for any hacker reliant on AI breakers, so long as it's timed to activate when there aren't any Clone Chips, Deus Exes, and Sharpshooters in play. The few ICE we've leased from other companies, HB's Viper and NBN's Tollbooth, fit our goals of taxing runners, whether it's through their time or bank accounts.

I think that's all I had to mention regarding our ICE. I'll hand this back over to our Chairman.

Slide: Can It All Be So Simple // Agendas

HIRO: Before we get into the Q&A, I'd like to mention that we have some very exciting opportunities ahead of Jinteki. Thanks to our ties to the New Angeles PD -- through Commissioner Dawn and Ms. Caprice Nisei's work there -- as well as the nature of our classified artificial intelligence projects, it's become more difficult and expensive for opponents to steal our work. With developments down the line like our Future Perfect program, we can make it near impossible.

We also have other non-cloning advancements we'll announce in the near future, coming out of our biomedical Harmony Medtech division and our stealth groups at the Tennin Institute. That's not to say we intend to pivot our focus away from cloning, however. Cloning has the potential to replicate perfection. Let me repeat that: cloning has the potential to replicate perfection. Should we aspire to anything less?

With that, I'd like to open the cast to your questions.

name: NovaBiotics - 16th in Flight 2 at GenCon and 38th in the fin
description:
This was the corp deck that I took to GenCon flight 2 and to the finals.

The big difference is that I drop the 3rd biotic labor for two archers, which straight up won me games by trashing a rig.

There is also only a single SanSan and that is an artifact from the deck I played in flight one, and me not wanting to overhaul the deck too much before the second flight.

name: Moon Archery
description: A close deck to any Yellow Jackets, but going for Archer instead of Shinobi. Strong Eco, fast draw and Inazuma + Archer for strong punish. Lotus Field is a winner against Yog.0

name: Kate PPVP - 16th flight 2 at GenCon and 38th in the finals.
description:
The big change from the traditional PPVP deck is that I use ProCon, I prefer the consistent economy that ProCon offers, however it lacks burst card draw which was an issue in a few matches.

ProCon on the other hand won me matches against Jinteki PE which i faced twice.

name: Border Jumper, Job Stealer
New Andy
description: New optimized Andy for the tournaments.

name: Rebuilding Tokyo 2.0
description: NAPD ARE GEOTHERMAL AND A CORPORATE WAR

name: PrePaid Kate
Cache Money Millin'
description: Install them caches make money mill fools

name: The Iron House of Kikai
description:
Directly inspired by Iron House, posted by kikai:

http://netrunner.meteor.com/decks/Dr5nawviorL3XZoFx/

name: THE BIG F
Noise Cache
Noise Cache v2
Cowards Die in Shame
description:
Where the fear has gone there will be nothing. Only I will remain. -Bene Jesserit

Be fearless. You are not here to hide behind ice. Your walls are knives, ever welcoming your guest to step forward at the price of one more drop of blood.

Mushin no Shin, then advance to create servers the runner cannot afford to test, but cannot afford to leave unchecked. Install unadvanced (Snare), then triple advance (Junebug), then advance one last time and let them sit (Ronin).

Reclamation Order is your best friend. Celebrity Gift three turns in a row, showing them the same Shocks and Snares couching a singleton Fetal AI. Spend turn after turn dropping 4 pt remotes from hand.

Best of all, there is no glory like advancing three servers a point each and going from zero to seven in a single turn.

name: Veterans Hospital
What's that new Noise?
Bit by Bit Tennin
description: First draft of what came to mind when I saw Paywall Implementation. With one of these out you get rewarded regardless of what the runner does.

name: Will-o'-the-Wayland
description: An update to the old Weyland idea of just doing nasty things to the runner's rig. Now with Will-o'-the-wisp it has the added edge that anything else they get through, you can knock something out of the rig to tax the runner more tutors and credits.
